head.hi: Truby's Remarks on Questionnaire for General Kean

list.item:
No. 1 *
I think that you and Kean have the right slant on this.
There are some discrepancies in Howard's statements about Reed,
Carroll, and Lazear which I have noted in pencil on the copy
you sent me. Howard's quotation from Reed “I went into this
line of work without instructions” is very important. Howard
believed Reed and so do I. After Carrolls death I found
that I could not audit Agramonte's statements. Before that
date his published statement were o.k.

No. 2 *
I think Mrs. Lazear was right and as we had applied for a
laboratory man at Camp Columbia, where we had both malaria and
dengue fevers, Lazear and the Surgeon General probably decided
that this was an ideal place for him to work. (See my book,
pages 57, 82, and 83.

No. 3 *
I feel confident that Reed first met Lazear at Camp Columbia.
Reed became interested in Lazear's work there and when Reed returned
to the States, someone told me (perhaps Reed himself) that when
the question of organizing the Board was considered, Reed consulted
Dr. Welch about it.Lazear- (Page 57).

No. 4
See my book, Page 76 & 181. When Reed reported to the Surgeon
General about his work on electrozone, he was ready to start a
real investigation of yellow fever and he no doubt recommended to
the Surgeon General in strong terms that he be sent back to Cuba
with proper assistance and facilities to do that work. Sternberg
naturally would concur and the Surgeon General deserves the credit
for organizingcreating the Board.

No. 5
See my book p. 76 & p. 38
Reed naturally selected Carroll as one member of the Board.
I think he/also/selected Lazear on Welch's recommendation and
because he had seen the fine work which Lazear was doing in Cuba.
Perhaps both Reed and Sternberg agreed on Agramonte as a member.
I have always understood that Reed wanted an immune to do autopsies
on yellow fever cases. He knew Agramonte and knew he was doing
this kind of work in Havana. Agramonte did Patrick Smith's
Autopsy and Reed knew about that.

No. 6
I never knew that the words “especially yellow fever” were
ommitted from the orders creating the Yellow Fever Board until
you told about it. Those words may have been deleted in the
AGO so as not to alarm people at home.

No. 7
I do not know.

No. 8
That would, I think, be impossible.

No. 9
You will remember that I wrote you that the “distinguished”
man in citizen's clothes was Reed. That was before I knew that
Blossom Reed had identified it as a photograph of her father.
The picture must have been taken in January or early in February,
1900, just as Reed was ready to leave for the U.S. I consider that
a very important photograph and I hope you will include it as an
illustration in your book. I was evidently taken on a cold day
as some of the personnel were wearing heavy blue uniforms. Kissinger
appears in his new acting steward's uniform. That alone practically
fixes the date of the photograph.

No. 10
No comment.

No. 11 *
There was no secrecy about the nature of the Board's work
except while Lazear was working alone on human guinea pigs. The
experiments with mosquitoes naturally was secret at that time
because authority had not been obtained tothe C. O. had not been consulted about jeopardizeing human
lives even with their consent. When Camp Lazear was opened, there
was no necessity for secrecy because the work had been approved
by General Wood and the experiments were not conducted at Camp Columbia. (Off the Post)

No. 12
The Surgeon General can only recommend and cannot xx give
orders to personnel except in his own Department (See my book,
Page 120).

No. 13
I never knew about Finlay's work at the Finca San Jose.

No. 14
I will give you a photograph of the building which I took myself.

No. 15
My recollection is that the Spanish immigrants were camped
near Regla across the bay near Cabana.

No. 16 *
I recollected distinctly that Reed made several trips to Havana
to consult with General Wood's Headquarters and possibly the Spanish
Consul about using Spanish volunteers for his experiments. (See my
book, page 182.)

No. 17 *
The Spanish Consul-General in Cuba made might have some corres-
pondence and records about the Spanish volunteers. It would be
worth trying.

No. 18
I certainly got the “insurance” ideas from Reed. Of course,
- 3 -
Mrs. Lazear was not present and nobody knew whether Lazear
had insurance or not. Possibly Reed himself, who probably did
have x insurance, wondered if they would jeopardize it by being
innoculated with infected mosquitoes. See p. 123

No. 19
Kean has answered that fully.

No. 20
No comment.

No. 21
No comment except the reference on Page 82 of my book.

No. 22.
No comment.

No. 23 *
Reed did not need any plans for the buildings. He knew what
he wanted in order to make his experiments fool-proof. Then he
wrote out the detailed specifications and also supervised the
work of construction personally. See p. 140

No. 24.
Kean was not only enthusiastic, he was also efficient and did
everything he could to help Reed with his plans.

No. 25
No comment.

No. 26
I concur with Kean.

No. 27
I concur with Kean. Also see my book Page 32.

No. 28
No comment.

No. 33 No.
No.

No. 34
Carroll did not believe in the mosquito theory. He did not want to
be bitten and in that frame of mind simply went on and did his routine
work regardless of consequences. No wonder Reed was disturbed.

No. 35*
No comment.

No. 36
No comment.

No. 37
It must be in the Surgeon General's Office but I think not
under the title “Roll of Honor”. As I understood it, it contained
information pertaining to these yellow fever experiments and
posibly the corresponence in the Roll of Honor.

No. 38*
Kean thinks that I gave him that story. I doubt it although
I think Reed did say that about Pinto. Reed liked Pinto and
as Pinto rarely left the post, he would have been a good case
and would have substantiated XY's case. Carroll's case, of
course, proved nothing.

No. 39*
No comment. I know nothing on that.

No. 40
No comment.

No. 41
I know that I wrote to Mrs. Lazear after her husband's death.
A few days later Kean came to see me at the Hospital (after the
funeral) and I told him I had written to Mrs. Lazear and then he
said “That's fine I have written her also”. This is one thing I am positive about.

No. 42.
I know nothing about it.

No. 43
I do not know.
Page 5.

From here on I will omit questions about which I can add nothing important.
The page numbers refer to my book.
47. See page 122.
48. See page 123.
50. See page 185.
51. See page 233, Senate Document.

53. See page 113. I think that the doctors were more depressed than anyone
else because in spite of all of our efforts we had an epidemic in our midst.
Truby's answers to your questionnaire for Kean, June 5, 1946:

65. Possibly Kean did do Agramonte an injustice when he stated that Agramonte
had nothing to do with mosquito work after Lazear's death, but Kean knew
in 1904 or 1905 (when he probably wrote Chapter 2 of the Senate Document)
that Agramonte “did not participate in the early mosquito work.” (Page 16).
See the same statement on page 21, Senate Document, also probably written
by Kean. I knew those facts also, so from the time I first saw Agramonte's
statement of 1908 (on page 26, Senate Document) I lost all my respect for
Agramonte. Likewise, I had previously lost all respect for Carroll for
similar statements re his work. Carroll made no false statements before
Reed died. Likewise, Agramonte made none that I know of until Carroll was
dead. (Dr. Hench, please read Chapter 2, Senate Document very carefully
and you will find answers to several important questions you have asked
Kean and me). (Unclean conditions, Carter's findings, human experiments,
General Wood's action). The last sentence on page 16 may be very important.
I don't know that I have ever seen that article. Chapter 2 probably con-
tains the most reliable information available on the points mentioned as
the subject was fresh in Kean's mind then and no controversies had arisen.

73. I think so. Both he and Reed, with Carter's findings and Ross' work
before them, saw the possibility or probability that yellow fever was
mosquito-borne. I have heard the story of Mrs. Stark's courage re the
Edmunds child. That is essentially true. Mrs. Stark's story about her
two boys spilling black vomit over themselves is okay except that I am
sure the specimens belonged to Ames and not to Reed. I think they were
standing on the porch railing as I told you. I don't know anything re the
Carroll laboratory specimens.

75. The doctors all knew that Carroll was disgruntled and sore because he had
to permit an infected mosquito to bite him. He did not believe in the
theory; likewise, he did not want to have anything to do with it. He
refused to let Lazear put more than one infected mosquito on his arm.
77. Ravanel gave us the answer.
Page 6.

78. Kean and the doctors at Camp Columbia accepted it at once (after Lazear's results) and our en-
thusiasm was promptly transmitted and accepted by the whole garrison.
Likewise, when the information came out in the papers the Cubans accep-
ted it also. (After the Additional Report was read.)
81. They were very brave, not panicky.

84. See page 111. We had a band and the casket was draped with a flag and
carried on a caisson. Lazear's body was not taken to the cemetery in an
ambulance as you seemd to think.

86. He died at the “U.S.A. General Hospital,” Washington Barracks, D. C. Reed's
operation was performed in the operating room of that hospital. A picture
of that room and the general conditions, including most of the personnel,
is shown on page 195 of my book.

91. See my reply to Question 65 above. I never had any trouble with Agramonte.
The Contract Surgeons, however, disliked him. He was very pompous and
aggressive and senior to all the other doctors. He never let them forget
that fact. I know that Lazear and Agramonte were not close friends,
although they were classmates.

92. General Frederick F. Russell can tell you all about Dr. Noguchi. Russell
was in charge of the Health Department work of the Rockefeller Foundation
at the time Noguchi was with them. I am sure that Russell had more to do
with the early Rockefeller yellow fever research work than anyone else.
Russell and I were very close friends throughout his service in the Army.
We were often stationed together and he told me all about Noguchi and his
peculiarities. I think that I have seen it in print also. Be sure and
communicate with Russell and meet him if you can. He can give you much
information.

93. See page 19, Senate Document. When Reed found out exactly what Lazear had
done with his mosquitoes just prior to his death, I think he must have
consulted Gen. Wood and they then decided to publish Lazear's experiments
as described in the Preliminary Note. No doubt it was also then decided
by these two great men to continue the same line of experiments on human
subjects in order to prove Lazear's unconclusive results. (See my book,
pages 127 to 134 and page 19, Senate Document). XY's case convinced Reed
that he could prove the theory and Gen. Wood must have told him to go ahead at that time.

94. See Senate Document, pages 9, 15 and 16, and my book, page 91. See also
Dr. Victor Vaughan's remarks on page 178 in his book “A Doctor's Memories.”

95. See my book, pages 89 to 90. I think, however, that Kean's quoting of
Reed's remarks gives us the true answer to the way Sternberg felt about
the insect theory.

96. Personally, I had never questioned Sternberg's statements even as late as
when I wrote my book. I even felt surprised and somewhat shocked at Reed's
Page 7.
statement in his letter to his wife on December 11, 1900, predicting that
Dr. X__ would state that he had considered the mosquito theory as the most
probable cause of yellow fever. See Kelly, page 143, First Edition.

97. See Note, page 217 of the Sternberg Biography. Agramonte quoting a letter
from Reed written in 1900, says “verbalinstructions” as to the cause of
yellow fever. Personally I have never seen any written instructions except
those referred to above and in the reprint of the Popular Science Monthly
of July 1901, which I gave you when you were here in 1943. Also see my
book, pages 89 to 90.
98. I concur with Kean's answer.

99. I concur in Kean's answer. Regarding your remarks about this question, I
think that a scientific board of that kind would naturally be directed to
study all diseases which were causing mortality and morbidity among our
troops in Cuba. Of these diseases, however, yellow fever was the great
monster which we knew so little about and as Reed was already investigating
that disease, naturally he wanted to finish the work and discover the
etiology of yellow fever if possible. Regarding Kober, I told you what
close friends he and Sternberg were and I think Agramonte was close to
both of them.

100. Lazear, while he was still living in Baltimore, was deeply interested in
malaria and no doubt that fact took him to see Howard in Washington regard-
ing mosquitoes.

102. Reed started that story when he was writing the Preliminary Report. The
“Insurance story” was just a surmise on his part as he knew nothing of
Lazear's personal affairs. I have explained that elsewhere.

106. Reed was living at Camp Columbia by War Department orders. See Sternberg's
Biography, page 214. Therefore, the Commanding Officer could not interfere
with that. However, if the CO found him jeopardizing the lives of his men
or if Reed was actually introducing yellow fever to the Post, he could
have stopped the work at once unless Gen. Wood had previously directed
otherwise. When Camp Lazear was established it was not near the reser-
vation and was therefore beyond the control or jurisdiction of the CO. By
that time, too, the Military Governor (Wood) had authorized experimentation
on volunteers. That fact was generally known and the papers made a fuss
about it. Reed and the CO, Col. Baldwin, were on friendly terms. Reed
frequently went to the Post parties and you may be sure that he officially
called on the CO very promptly - that was a very strict requirement in
those days.

107. I have given the answer in the preceding paragraph. I hold that nothing
was secret until Lazear started his experiments on soldiers with infected
mosquitoes. No doubt Gen. Wood had approved their doing that but Lazear,
in his haste, had probably not consulted the CO on this important matter.
ThisThings went faster than he had anticipated. Neither he nor Reed probably
expected any results in the early stages of the experiments with mosquitoes.
112. I concur in Kean's answer.
